page.title: 09Farmland in Silverdale
page.content: There is very little land in this area south of Silverdale, and therefore very little farming. Sheep owned by several farmers are grazed on the marshlands. When the tides are high,(twice a lunar month)the sheep have to be brought off the foreshore. This is quite a task because of the many channels where the sheep can easily hide and then be drowned by the incoming tide. Many are kept in a disused quarry until they can be allowed back.(One farmer travels from Grange each day to see his sheep). Dairy cows are also grazed on the higher ground (Jack Scout and Heald Brow) and at the foot of Warton Crag, where the fields are fertile, provided the water level is controlled by an electric pumping system.
